title: 104_s762
content:
The Act titled "Medicare Billing Abuse Prevention Act of 1995" aims to address billing code abuse in the Medicare program. The General Accounting Office suggests using commercial software to detect abuse, potentially saving taxpayers $2,000,000 per day. Regulatory requirements may hinder the prompt implementation of such software. The Act requires Medicare carriers to acquire commercial ADPE within 90 days to identify billing code abuse in processing Medicare part B claims. The ADPE must be used as a supplement to existing systems and be standardized for uniformity. Carriers must implement the ADPE within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. MINIMUM SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS.

The ADPE must be a commercial item and surpass the capabilities of previous systems used for processing Medicare part B claims. It should be modifiable to meet statutory requirements and general policies of the Health Care Financing Administration.

SEC. 5. DISCLOSURE. SEC. 5. DISCLOSURE. ADPE or data acquired by medicare carriers shall not be publicly disclosed, except with Secretary's authorization if in the public interest and not protected under section 552(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 6. The Secretary will review existing regulations on medicare payment policies and billing code abuse within 30 days of the Act's enactment to determine if revisions are needed to maximize benefits of ADPE use. The Act defines key terms such as "automatic data processing equipment," "billing code abuse," "commercial item," "medicare part B," and "medicare carrier." The term "medicare carrier" refers to an entity contracted by the Health Care Financing Administration to handle Medicare Part B payments and related functions. "Payment policies" are regulations governing billing code abuses. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
